adjective.description: Smooth and even; without marked lumps or indentations.
examples: trim the surface of the cake to make it completely flat

adjective.description: Lacking interest or emotion; dull and lifeless.
examples: “I'm sorry,” he said, in a flat voice
her drawings were flat and unimaginative

adjective.description: (of a sparkling drink) having lost its effervescence.
(of a fee, wage, or price) the same in all cases, not varying with changed conditions or in particular cases.
(of musical sound) below true or normal pitch.

adverb.description: In or to a horizontal position.
examples: he was lying flat on his back
she had been knocked flat by the blast
she was going to be flat broke in a couple of days

adverb.description: Below the true or normal pitch of musical sound.
examples: it wasn't a question of singing flat, but of simply singing the wrong notes
she placed the flat of her hand over her glass

noun.description: An upright section of painted stage scenery mounted on a frame.
A musical note lowered a semitone below natural pitch.

examples: “blue” harmony emphasizing the flatted third and seventh

phrases: Admittedly, most of the cast lack the comic timing to make all the jokes fly, but for every joke that does fall flat there are at least two more that work.
I was afraid that all my jokes were falling flat.
I considered cheering her up with maybe a joke or something, but my jokes always fall flat.
However, the script fails him by falling flat in the moments where you expect the most to be delivered.
origin: Early 19th century (denoting a floor or storey): alteration of obsolete flet floor, dwelling, of Germanic origin and related to flat.
